title: The truth_______s still elusive
full text:
Serious career consequences for four of its own officials following release of the State Department Accountability Review BoardÐ²Ð‚â„¢s report on the Sept. 11 attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi are fitting, but more is needed to assuage well-founded concerns about that fatal fiasco and its aftermath. 
The reportÐ²Ð‚â„¢s unclassified public version blames Ð²Ð‚Ñšsystematic failures and leadership and management deficienciesÐ²Ð‚Ñœ at State for the deaths of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans at the compound in Libya. 
It says the Benghazi security plan, Ð²Ð‚ÑšinadequateÐ²Ð‚Ñœ for months prior, was Ð²Ð‚Ñšgrossly inadequateÐ²Ð‚Ñœ to repel the attack, despite Ð²Ð‚Ñšrepeated requestsÐ²Ð‚Ñœ for more security staff. Appropriately, Eric Boswell, assistant secretary of diplomatic security, has resigned, and his deputy, Charlene Lamb, is among three officials placed on administrative leave. 
The report also says Ð²Ð‚Ñšthere was no protestÐ²Ð‚Ñœ before the attack, contradicting initial administration spin about reaction to an anti-Muslim, U.S.-made video. But thatÐ²Ð‚â„¢s a long way from fully explaining why the Obama administration took so long to get its Benghazi story straight Ð²Ð‚â€ and from accountability for what looks like an attempted cover-up of a botched response to terrorism. 
The Obama White House not only must tell the whole Benghazi truth; it must impose consequences on all who are culpable Ð²Ð‚â€ and ensure that more Americans do not suffer the fate of Mr. Stevens and his colleagues. 

Load-Date: December 25, 2012
